title: Keeping Up With Tech Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of strategies for staying current in web development.

questions.question: Which approach is most effective for learning a new technology?

options.text: Watching dozens of tutorial videos without building anything
Building a small project that uses the technology to solve a real problem
Reading the entire documentation before writing any code
Waiting until the technology is 5+ years old before trying it

questions.explanation: Hands-on practice with a real project solidifies learning far more effectively than passive consumption. Building something forces you to understand concepts deeply.

questions.question: You should adopt every new JavaScript framework that becomes popular to stay current.
questions.explanation: Chasing every new tool leads to shallow knowledge. It's better to deeply understand fundamentals and selectively evaluate new technologies based on real project needs.

questions.question: Which is the most reliable source for web platform documentation?
questions.explanation: MDN Web Docs is the gold standard for web platform documentation. It's maintained by Mozilla with contributions from browser vendors and is regularly updated and peer-reviewed.

questions.question: What is 'tutorial hell'?

options.text: When tutorials have errors in them
Endlessly following tutorials without building original projects or solving real problems
When there are too many tutorials on a topic
Tutorials that are too difficult to follow

questions.explanation: Tutorial hell is the cycle of completing tutorials without developing the ability to build things independently. Breaking out requires attempting projects beyond your comfort zone.

questions.question: Which is the best way to evaluate whether a new technology is worth learning?

options.text: Check how many GitHub stars it has
See if influencers are talking about it
Evaluate if it solves a real problem you face and has a healthy community and maintenance track record
Only learn it if your company mandates it

questions.explanation: Evaluate technologies based on: does it solve a real problem? Is it actively maintained? Does it have good documentation? Is there community support? What's the migration/adoption cost?
